Vermund, M.D., Ph.D. Chief, Vaccine Trials and Epidemiology Branch Division of AIDS National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases, NIH Solar Building, Room 2A42 6003 Executive Boulevard Rockville, MD 20892-9902 (301) 496-6177 (301) 402-1506 (FAX) David Vlahov, Ph.D. Assistant Professor Division of Epidemiology School of Hygiene and Public Health Johns Hopkins University 624 North Broadway, Room 897 Baltimore, MD 21205 Adjuvant--a substance that enhances the immunogenic properties of an antigen, or the pharmacological effects of a drug. Only one adjuvant--alum--is approved by the Food and Drug Administration for use in vaccines in humans. Novel adjuvants may help improve the immunogenicity of many candidate HIV vaccines. Adverse Reaction (side effect)--an. unwanted negative reaction to an experimental drug or vaccine. AIDS--the late stage of a disease caused by HIV infection, characterized by deterioration of the immune system and a range of opportunistic infections and malignancies. Antibodies--soluble proteins produced by white blood cells (B lymphocytes) in response to antigens, which can bind to or neutralize the antigens. Antigen--any material that can elicit an immune response when introduced into Che body. Arm--a group of subjects in a clinical trial, all of whom receive the same treatment or intervention, or placebo (e.g. the control arm, the active arm, the experimental arm). Asymptomatic--without symptoms. Someone who is HIV-infected but asymptomatic may have produced HIV antibodies but does not have any visible signs or symptoms of disease. Attenuated--weakened or decreased; an attenuated pathogen, which is no longer able to produce disease, is sometimes used to produce a vaccine. Blinded Study--a clinical trial in which participants are unaware whether they are in the experimental or the control arm of the study. Booster--a second or subsequent dose of a vaccine given to increase the immunological response to the original dose. Breakthrough lection--an infection that occurs during the course of a vaccine trial. CBO--community-based organization. CDC--Centers for Disease. Control and Prevention, headquartered in Atlanta, Ga., an agency of the Public Health Service, Department of Health and Human Services. HIV PREVENTIVE VACCINES: SOCIAL, ETHICAL, AND POLITICAL CONSIDERATIONS FOR DOMESTIC EFFICACY TRIALS [Page 51](https://quod.lib.umich.edu/c/cohenaids/5571095.0082.015/28) DRAFT-- 51 Challenge--exposure (of a vaccinee or a participant in a vaccine trial) to the infectious agent. CIOMS--Council of International Organizations of Medical Sciences. Clade--a related subset of HIV quasispecies. HIV variants are currently classified according to degree of genetic similarity into clades A, B, C, D, E, F, and O. Cohort--a group of individuals who share one or more characteristics for purposes of a clinical research study. Controlled Clinical Trial--a trial in which one group of subjects (sometimes referred to as an "arm" of the trial) is idministered an experimental drug or vaccine and another group is administered either a placebo or a standard treatment or vaccine. Participants are usually unaware of which group they are in. Correlates of Immunity (also Correlates of Protective Immunity)--a measurable marker that indicates immunity (in diseases other than HIV the presence of antibodies often serves as a correlate of immunity); such markers allow the determination of immunity without direct "challenge." Cytotoxic T Lymphocyte (CTL)--white blood cell that destroys infected directly; nicknamed T cell." Most CTLs are CD8+ T lymphocytes. Double-Blind--a type of clinical trial in which both subjects and investigators are unaware of which participants are enrolled in the experimental arm and which are enrolled in the control arm. Blinding is used to reduce or eliminate bias. DSMB--Data and Safety Monitoring Board. An independent committee comprised of clinical research experts, who review unblinded data while a trial is in progress to ensure that neither arm is exposed to undue risk, either by virtue of the experimental arm proving either far superior or far inferior to the control arm. The DSMB is empowered to modify the protocol or terminate the trial. ELISA--enzymlinked immunoabsorbent assay, a blood test commonly used to detect HIV antibodies. In public health settings, a positive ELISA test, indicating previous HIV infection, generally must be confirmed by the more sensitive Western Blot test. FDA--The Food and Drug Administration, headquartered in Rockville, Md., an agency of the Public Health Service, Department of Health and Human Services. HIV PREVENTIVE VACCINES: SOCIAL, ETHICAL, AND POLITICAL CONSIDERATIONS FOR DOMESTIC EFFICACY TRIALS [Page 52](https://quod.lib.umich.edu/c/cohenaids/5571095.0082.015/29) DRAFT-- 52 Genome--genetic material, DNA in a cell, DNA or RNA in a virus. gpl20--glycoprotein 120, a protein on the envelope (coating) of HIV. HIV--human immunodeficiency virus, the retrovirus that causes AIDS. HIV Disease--the spectrum of immunodeficiency and disease associated with HIV infection. Homologous--similar in appearance, structure, or function; usually applied to the same species. Host--an organism harboring an infection (e.g. bacteria or virus). Immunity--natural or acquired resistance to infectious disease by virtue of previous exposure to the causative organism. Immunity may be partial or complete, long-lasting or temporary. Immunization--protection against disease via vaccination, usually with a weakened form of the agent that causes illness. Immunogen--material capable of provoking an immune response (an antigen). Immunogenic--capable of provoking an immune response. Immunosuppression--suppression of immune response. Inclusion/Exclusion Criteria--the medical or social characteristics on the basis of which individuals or groups may be included or excluded from participating in clinical trials. Informed Consent--the process by which prospective subjects agree voluntarily, and based on information about risks and benefits, as well as alternatives, to participate in a clinical research experiment. Inoculate--to introduce the agent of a disease or other antigenic material into the blood for preventive, cura#ve, or experimental purposes. IRB--institutional review board, an independent ethical review panel designated to review trial protocols prior to their commencement, to ensure that the rights of human subjects are being adequately protected. HIV PREVENTIVE VACCINES: SOCIAL, ETHICAL, AND POLITICAL CONSIDERATIONS FOR DOMESTIC EFFICACY TRIALS [Page 53](https://quod.lib.umich.edu/c/cohenaids/5571095.0082.015/30) DRAFT-- 53 Mucosal Imunwity--resistance to infection via the mucous membranes, by virtue of immune cells lining the genital tract, oral cavity, etc. Neutralization--action by neutralizing antibodies that keeps a virus from infecting a cell, usually by blocking receptors on the cell or the virus. NIAID--National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases, headquartered in Bethesda, Md., and an agency of the National Institutes of Health. The institute supports research on AIDS, tuberculosis, and other infectious diseases as well as allergies and immunology. NIH--National Institutes of Health, headquartered in Bethesda, Md., an agency of the U.S. Public Health Service, U.S. Department of Health and Human Services. Opportunistic Infection--in an immunocompromised person, an infectious disease caused by an organism that generally would be nonpathogenic in an immune-competent host. Parenteral--involving introduction into the bloodstream. Pathogen--any virus, microorganism, or other substance causing disease. Peptide--chain of two or more amino acids. Proteins are large peptides. Phase I--the first clinical studies of a drug or vaccine in humans. Designed to evaluate shortterm toxicity (adverse reactions) at different dose levels. Involves a small number of healthy (or, in the study of vaccines, low-risk) volunteers, for a relatively short period of time. Phase H--larger clinical trials involving greater numbers of volunteers, some of whom may be ill (or, in the study of vaccines, at higher risk for infection). Phase H trials follow the demonstration of preliminary safety through Phase I studies, and gather longer-term safety and dosage data. Phase II studies may suggest efficacy but do not have the statistical power to be conclusive. Phase llI--large, well-controlled clinical trials designed to demonstrate the efficacy of a drug or vaccine in a.atistically meaningful manner. Phase III trials also confirm preliminary Phase I and II safety data and, if successful, are used to justify licensure. Placebo--an inactive substance administered to a group of study participants (an "arm" of the trial) who serve as a control group, to provide a basis of comparison with those being administered the experimental drug or vaccine. HIV PREVENTIVE VACCINES: SOCIAL, ETHICAL, AND POLITICAL CONSIDERATIONS FOR DOMESTIC EFFICACY TRIALS [Page 54](https://quod.lib.umich.edu/c/cohenaids/5571095.0082.015/31) DRAFT-- 54 Polymerase--an enzyme that promotes synthesis of segments of DNA and RNA. Polyvalent Vaccine--a vaccine that is protective against multiple viral strains. Prevalence--the number of cases of disease, expressed as a percentage, in a population at a given time. Preventive vaccine--an immunogepn administered to prevent disease. Protocol--a detailed plan for a clinical trial that states the trial's rationale, purpose, drug or vaccine dosages, length of study, route of administration, who may participate (inclusion/exclusion criteria), etc. Reactogenicity--the capacity to produce adverse reactions, or side effects. Recombinant--a genome or organism that has been manipulated to insert genetic material from a different organism. Regulatory Genes--HIV genes (e.g. nef, rey, _t) that regulate viral replication in infected cells. rgpl20--recombinant glycoprotein 120. Seroconversion--the development of antibodies specific to a particular antigen. Seroincidence--the number of new infections, expressed as a percentage, in a population during a given period of time. Seroprevalence--the number of infected individuals, expressed as a percentage, in a population at any given time. Serostatus--results (usually positive or negative) of a test for a specific antibody (e.g. seropositive or seronegative; or HIV positive or HIV negative.) SHIV--genetically constructed hybrid virus having an HIV envelope on an SIV core. SIV--simian immunodeficiency virus. STD--sexually transmitted disease. HIV PREVENTIVE VACCINES: SOCIAL, ETHICAL, AND POLITICAL CONSIDERATIONS FOR DOMESTIC EFFICACY TRIALS [Page 55](https://quod.lib.umich.edu/c/cohenaids/5571095.0082.015/32) DRAFT-- 55 Sterilizing Immunity--complete protection from disease via elimination of infection. Surrogate Marker--an indirect model or indicator of disease progression. In HIV disease, the number of CD4+ cells P" cb t ' is a nonvalidated surrogate marker for progression of disease. There are no known reliable surrogate markers for HIV disease. T Cell, T Lymphocyte--white blood cells that are critical to the immune response. They are divided into CD4+ (mostly T helper cells) and CD8+ (mostly killer T cells, and possibly suppressor T cells). Therapeutic Vaccine--a vaccine that is designed to attenuate disease in a previously infected individual. Unblinding--the intentional or inadvertent discovery by subjects or investigators in a blinded clinical trial of who is on the control arm or who is on the active arm of the trial. In HIV vaccine trials, unblinding can occur when subjects obtain HIV-antibody test results outside the context of trial participation, potentially learning whether they have received the,.placebo or a candidate vaccine. Vector--a bacterium or virus, genetically altered to be nonpathogenic, used to transport an antigen into the body in order to stimulate the production of protective immunity. Virion/Pseudovirion--a complete virus particle; virus-like agents genetically engineered without having been derived from HIV. WHO--World Health Organization.
